column4: oops psted the wrong line i meant to say: is it better to install generic or linux-amd64-k8   on an AMD64 turion ?
it doesn't really matter
not ndiswrapper
generic does not mean that it's not 64bit
if you run 'uname -a' you'll see that your kernel is x86_64
internal devices can be connected to the USB
but why would it disapear when its still got to be physically connected ?
this can happen if the laptop BIOS has the capability to power the internal device down.
so it cant be fixed using some special lsusb command? :(
explain what the exact problem is please
i have a webcam (m5602 not supported) and it sometimes shows in lsusb, thats about all i know
do you dualboot Windows?
nope, vista doesnt work since i shrunk it.
if you disable the webcam in the BIOS setup, it probably won't be seen by lsusb any more.
i was trying to get the camera working, but i suppose if its a bios problem theres not much i can do
so the real problem is that you can't get your webcam to work?
well i can get it to work when its in lsusb but it not when its not
so when does it disappear?
sometimes its not there when i start the laptop othertimes it disapears if i swivel the camera around
I think it has a wobbly internal connection
so it pobably needs taking to a computer shop ? where theyll probably tell me ubuntu is unsupprted :(
thx for the help
if you find a shop with reasonably competent people, and you tell them that your camera disconnects when you swivel it, they will probably be willing to help you.
